heading: passage: thomas yohe, 63
subheading: thomas yohe, co-creator of the emmy-winning schoolhouse rock cartoons, died of cancer at his home in norwalk, connecticut last week. he was 63. yohe was the creative director for many of the hit three-minute cartoons that ran from 1973 to 1985, including "conjunction junction" and "i'm just a bill." the series entertained a generation of american children with educational ditties about grammar, math, civics and history, earning four emmy awards and a place in the popular culture. "he was almost like a pied piper," said radford stone, co-producer on the series and a longtime friend. "he was the life-blood and the heart and the soul of the show." it was so popular, stone said, that a generation of americans between the ages of 25 and 40 say they now buy videotapes to show their own kids.
